titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Vicki Hearne Papers
titlestmt.author: by Susan Brady

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:54

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Vicki Hearne Papers consist of correspondence, writings, personal papers, photographs, audiocassettes, and clippings that document the development of her writing, from her works of poetry in the 1970s, through the books and articles she wrote in defense of dogs at the turn of the twenty-first century. Her writings reveal the connection between her work as an animal trainer and as an author and poet, both vocations informed by her readings and interpretation of philosophers including Plato, Nietzsche, and Wittgenstein. Drafts of many of her works of poetry, non-fiction, and her book of fiction reveal the evolution of the works, and notes and comments by editors regarding works submitted for publication illustrate the nature of her relationship with her publishers. Letters from colleagues and friends, particularly her mentor, John Hollander, provide insight into the support she received from those individuals.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Bequest of Vicki Hearne, 2002, and gift of James Hearne, 2008.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 42-43: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
Box 44: Restricted until January 1, 2060. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Vicki Hearne Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Vicki Hearne Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

bioghist.head: Vicki Hearne (1946-2001)
bioghist.p: Victoria Elizabeth Hearne was born in Austin, Texas, on February 13, 1946, and grew up in a military family in Texas, Louisiana, and Mississippi. Hearne began her dog and horse training career in California in 1967, after learning she had a talent for the work when she trained her own dog under the mentorship of Hollywood animal trainers Bill and Dick Koehler. She continued to work with animals throughout her life. Having written poetry since her childhood, she studied writing and received a B.A. in English from the University of California, Riverside, in 1969. Hearne's published collections of poetry include Nervous Horses (1980), In the Absence of Horses (1983) and The Parts of Light (1994). Individual poems written by Hearne were published in magazines and journals including The New Republic , The Partisan Review , and Poetry . She was a Stegner Fellow in Poetry at Stanford University, and received a writing grant from the Ingram Merrill Foundation. In 1984, she was given the Peter I . B. Lavan Younger Poets Award from the Academy of American Poets. She taught creative writing at the University of California at Riverside from 1980 to 1984. From 1984 to 1986, she was an assistant professor of English at Yale, and she was a visiting fellow at the Institution for Social and Policy Studies at Yale from 1989 to 1995. Following her move to the Northeast, Hearne continued to train dogs at Silver Trails: The Animal Inn in Westbrook, Connecticut. Vicki Hearne and her first husband (from whom she was divorced in 1970) were the parents of a daughter, Colleen Lerman. Hearne married Robert Tragesser, a professor of philosophy, in 1983. She died of lung cancer in Branford, Connecticut on August 21, 2001.

Hearne's writing was informed by her work with dogs and horses and the philosophies of Plato, Nietzsche, and Wittgenstein, among others. She addressed issues of animal behavior and the ways in which animals communicate with humans in her books of nonfiction and in magazine and journal articles. She authored Adam's Task: Calling Animals by Name and Animal Happiness , and co-authored the book Horse Breaking: The Obedience Method with Bill Forest. Her articles "Talking With Dogs, Chimps and Others," and "How to Say Fetch," were published in Raritan in the early 1980s. She was published in American magazines including The Atlantic Monthly , Harper's , and The New Yorker , and in foreign publications including the Japanese edition of Esquire Magazine .

An ardent defender of breeds of dogs labeled by legal authorities as innately dangerous, Hearne served as an expert witness on dog behavior beginning in the 1980s. Her experiences while defending a dog (mistakenly identified as a pit bull) that had been sentenced to death for his biting offences in Stamford, Connecticut, were the subject of her book, Bandit: Dossier of a Dangerous Dog . After being granted custody of the dog for three months Hearne rehabilitated Bandit and was given permanent guardianship of the animal. She appeared in various media, gained an international following, and wrote numerous articles in which she spoke against city ordinances that banned particular breeds of dogs. The events surrounding the Bandit case were also chronicled in a documentary film, A Little Vicious , which was nominated for an Academy Award in 1992.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Vicki Hearne Papers consist of correspondence, writings, personal papers, photographs, audiotapes, and clippings. The papers span the years 1920 through 2005, with the bulk of the material dating from 1976 through 2001. Hearne's papers document the development of her writing, from her works of poetry in the 1970s, through the books and articles she wrote in defense of dogs at the turn of the twenty-first century. Her writings reveal the connection between two seemingly separate endeavors--her work as an animal trainer and as an author and poet--both vocations informed by her readings and interpretation of philosophers including Plato, Nietzsche, and Wittgenstein. Drafts of many of her works of poetry, non-fiction, and her book of fiction reveal the evolution of the works, and notes and comments by editors regarding works submitted for publication illustrate the nature of her relationship with her publishers. Letters from colleagues and friends, particularly her mentor, John Hollander, provide insight into the support she received from those individuals. Files relating to animal training and the material accompanying the drafts of her writings, particularly the Bandit case correspondence, case files, and clipping files, reveal her professional and personal connection to her own companion animals and to those of her friends and colleagues. While Hearne made her position on animal training, behavior, and rights clear in her writings, the research and clipping files provide additional background information on the subjects, and document the various points of view among law enforcement and legislators, members of various animal rights organizations, and dog trainers and breeders. Letters from dog breeders (particularly Roselma Elliot) with whom she had professional and personal relationships document not only the business of breeding and selling of dogs, but behaviorial and health issues of animals owned by Hearne and others as well.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series and one addition: I. Correspondence, 1976-2001. II. Writings, 1969-2001. III. Animal Records and Training Files, 1989-2001. IV. Personal Papers, 1920-2001. V. Photographs and Audiotapes, 1955-1992. 2008 Addition, 1983-2005.

controlaccess.subject: Animal rights activists -- United States -- Archives
Animal trainers -- United States -- Archives

Dogs -- Behavior
Horses -- Training
Poets, American -- 20th Century -- Archives

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into three subseries: Incoming, Outgoing, and Third Party, and dates from 1976 to 2001. With the exception of letters from unidentified correspondents, which are arranged chronologically, the letters are arranged alphabetically within each subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The majority of the incoming correspondence consists of letters received by Hearne regarding animal training and breeding, and the publication of her writings. Personal letters from family members include those from her daughter, Colleen Lerman, her brother Jim Hearne, and her mother, Elizabeth Hearne. Letters from her friend and mentor, John Hollander, and those written to Hearne by Roselma Elliott, a breeder of Airedales with whom Hearne became friends, form the largest groups of letters from individual correspondents. Outgoing correspondence consists of one folder of copies of letters regarding publications, including a letter to the editor of Harper's , Lewis Lapham, and a letter to Iris Murdoch regarding a proposed anthology. Several unsent mailings include a letter to her daughter. Third-party correspondence includes notes and letters sent to Robert Tragesser following Hearne's death in 2001. Drafts of letters written by Hearne may be found in the spiral notebooks in Series II. Additional correspondence regarding the Bandit case may be found in Series II.

did.unittitle: American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters
University of Southern California School of Urban and Regional Planning
Correspondents identified by first name, B-T

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is organized into seven subseries: Books, Articles and Presentations, Book Reviews, Short Stories and Plays, Poetry, Miscellaneous Writings, and Writings by Others. Within each subseries the material is arranged alphabetically by title or author.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes writings by Hearne and others dating from 1969 to 2001. Single drafts of titles are described individually. Titles represented by several drafts are described as "multiple drafts," and may include: typescript and holograph drafts, in original, photocopy, and mimeographed form, corrected by Hearne, and containing annotations by editors and proofreaders' marks. Additional materials include page proofs, contracts with publishers, cover letters, research files, publicity material, and reviews. Published versions of some of the magazine and journal articles are also included.

The subseries Books, consists of materials dating from 1984-2000, and includes various drafts of her published non-fiction works, Adams Task: Calling Animals by Name , Animal Happiness , Bandit: Dossier of a Dangerous Dog , and the work she co-authored with Bill Forest, Horse Breaking: The Obedience Method , as well as her novel, The White German Shepherd . Drafts of an unpublished work, "First Friend," are also included. The Bandit -related materials include research files, correspondence, case files, and other case documentation, as well as copies of the National "Pit Bull Terrier" Defense Association Newsletter , which she published in 1988-1989 to inform her friends and supporters of developments in the case.

The subseries Articles and Presentations, consists of drafts and published versions of works dating from 1982-2000, and includes her writings for journals and magazines, including the weekly "Animals" column she wrote for The Los Angeles Times Magazine from 1985 to 1986. While the majority of articles focus on issues of animal behavior and training, the subseries also contains material on other topics, including an obituary for her mentor William Koehler, and a draft of a biographical essay on her mother, "Ornery."
The subseries Book Reviews, contains Hearne's reviews of books on various animal-related subjects published in the The New York Times Book Review from 1984 to 1990.

The subseries Short Stories and Plays, consists of several stories including "The Spine of Eclipse"; "The Problem of Belief," written with her husband Robert Tragesser; and a play, "Fido: Play in 3 Strophes." While "Spine of Eclipse" is dated 1994, the other material is undated.

The subseries Poetry, consists of materials relating to her published poetry collections, including Nervous Horses and In the Absence of Horses , as well as files containing drafts of additional collections and individual poems, dating from the 1970s to 2001. The series contains a section of Other Poems, which consists of material that was removed from loose-leaf binders and hanging file folders for preservation purposes, but kept in the arrangement in which it was found within the original housing. Folder titles were transcribed from binders or labeled according to title or subject of poems. Folders of miscellaneous drafts of poetry may contain typescript and holograph drafts, in original, photocopy, and mimeographed form, corrected and/or annotated by Hearne or others.

The subseries Miscellaneous Writings, contains material removed from loose-leaf binders, spiral-bound notebooks, and folders for preservation purposes, and dates from 1981 to 2001. Binders were assigned numbers for ease of retrieval. The original order has been maintained as much as possible. In addition to the material listed, binders may contain various holograph and typescript notes, lists, mailing addresses, telephone numbers, etc. The spiral-bound notebooks contain a variety of writings, notes, anagrams, drafts of letters, addresses and telephone numbers, drawings and doodles, etc. Loose material found within the notebooks has been placed behind the notebook in each folder. Notebooks containing a predominant genre or topic are labeled as such and are filed in front of notebooks whose contents are more varied.

The subseries Writings of Others, consists of drafts, off-prints, and photocopies of published works by friends and other writers including Robert Tragesser, John Hollander, Harold Bloom, and Jorge Luis Borges, and date from 1972 to 2001.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The majority of material in this series consists of registrations and certificates for Hearne's companion animals. A small group of materials relates to dog training and information on various dog breeds and animal behavior. The material dates from 1989 to 2001.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains dog club registrations, obedience title certificates, and obedience trial ribbons; town registration and rabies certificates, and veterinary records.

did.unittitle: "The Obedience Method of Rebreaking and Rebalancing," typescript of a course outline
Waivers for obedience class taught by Hearne
Miscellaneous photocopies of published articles on animal behavior

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of a small number of legal, financial and medical documents, including Hearne's brief will; personal writings including a school notebook and notes relating to her illness; newspaper and magazine articles about, and interviews with, Hearne; two posters advertising Hearne readings; drawings by Katrin Wiese, sketchbooks containing drawings by unidentified artist(s), and miscellaneous publications and ephemera. The bulk of the material dates from 1968 to 2001.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by subject within each format category.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs of Hearne, family and friends, and dogs and horses, and date from 1955 to 1992. Additional photographs may be found as enclosures with correspondence in Series I, and with publicity material for Bandit in Series II. The series also contains two audiotapes.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The 2008 Addition consists of material given by Vicki Hearne's brother, James Hearne, in 2008.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The arrangement of the material corresponds with series headings in the main collection.
